name: Black and Tan
instructions: Chill both beers before pouring.
Fill a chilled pint glass halfway with the pale ale or lager.
Hold a spoon (bar spoon or special layering spoon) upside down over the glass just above the pale ale surface.
Slowly and gently pour the stout or porter over the back of the spoon so it floats on top, creating two distinct layers.
Serve immediately, without ice.
vibe: Casual and easy‑going layered beer mix
nameOrigin: From the contrasting colors — dark 'black' stout over pale 'tan' ale
history: Beer blending has been common in English alehouses since at least the 17th century. The term “Black and Tan” in reference to a beer mix appeared in print in 1881 in an American magazine; the first British reference is from 1889. The drink traditionally combines a pale ale or lager with a stout or porter. The layering effect is possible because stout has a lower density and floats atop the lighter beer. Although commonly associated with Ireland in modern pubs, the name can be politically sensitive there due to a historical paramilitary force called the Black and Tans — in Ireland the drink is often ordered as a “Half and Half.”
funFacts: The classic version uses English Bass Pale Ale and Irish Guinness Draught stout.
Some modern breweries sell ready‑mixed “Black & Tan” beer.
A specially bent spoon is often used to pour the stout gently and preserve the layers.

variations.name: Half and Half
variations.difference: Same drink but alternate name, especially used in Ireland (pale lager or ale + stout).

variations.name: Custom Layered Beer
variations.difference: Use any pale ale or lager and any stout/porter — layering works if densities differ.

tips: Use chilled beers — colder liquid helps maintain density difference.
Pour the stout slowly over the back of a spoon to avoid mixing layers.
If you pour stout too fast the beers will mix and you lose the layered look.

healthProfile.notes: Contains moderate calories and low sugar; alcohol content typical for beers.

name: Black Velvet
instructions: Chill both the stout and the sparkling wine, and chill a champagne flute or tall glass.
Pour the chilled stout beer into the glass to about half full.
Using a bar spoon (or regular spoon) turned upside down, gently pour the chilled sparkling wine over the back of the spoon so it floats atop the stout.
Serve immediately without ice.
nameOrigin: Named for the dark stout (‘black’) over sparkling wine (‘velvet’ colour), evocative of mourning dress tradition
history: The cocktail was first created in 1861 at Brooks’s Club in London to mourn the death of Prince Albert, consort to Queen Victoria. The stout’s dark colour symbolised mourning, layered over celebratory sparkling wine. Over time it evolved into an elegant yet simple mixed drink for celebrations. :contentReference[oaicite:0]{index=0}
funFacts: Originally created as a mourning cocktail for Prince Albert’s death. :contentReference[oaicite:1]{index=1}
Often made with stout and champagne, but sparkling wine, cider or perry can be used in variations. :contentReference[oaicite:2]{index=2}
Despite its somber origins, today it's typically enjoyed at brunches, celebrations, and parties. :contentReference[oaicite:3]{index=3}

variations.name: Poor Man’s Black Velvet
variations.difference: Replace the sparkling wine with apple cider or perry, layered with stout.

tips: Chill both the stout and sparkling wine thoroughly to help the layers remain distinct.
Pour the sparkling wine slowly over the back of a spoon to avoid mixing layers.
Serve in a chilled champagne flute for best presentation.

healthProfile.notes: Moderate alcohol and calories typical of a beer‑wine mixed drink

name: Boilermaker
drinkColor: Golden to amber (from beer) with whiskey hue
instructions: Chill the beer and whiskey if desired.
Pour the whiskey into a shot glass.
Pour the beer into a pint or beer glass (about 3/4 full).
Serve the beer glass alongside the shot glass.
Drink the whiskey (shoot) and then chase with the beer.
Alternatively, drop the shot glass into the beer and drink immediately (depth‑charge style), if preferred.
glassType: Pint glass for beer + shot glass for whiskey
nameOrigin: Named after 19th‑century boiler workers (boilermakers) who would drink whiskey and beer after work. :contentReference[oaicite:0]{index=0}
history: In 19th‑century America, workers who built and maintained steam boilers — known as boilermakers — would often end their shifts by drinking a shot of whiskey followed by a beer. The combination gradually became known simply as a “Boilermaker.” :contentReference[oaicite:1]{index=1} Over time it became a go‑to working‑class drink and later spread into wider bar culture. :contentReference[oaicite:2]{index=2}
funFacts: Originally a working‑class ritual among railroad and boiler workers. :contentReference[oaicite:3]{index=3}
Can be served two ways: shot then beer chaser, or shot dropped into beer (depth charge / bomb style). :contentReference[oaicite:4]{index=4}
Modern craft cocktail bars sometimes reimagine the Boilermaker with creative beer and whiskey (or other spirit) pairings. :contentReference[oaicite:5]{index=5}

variations.name: Depth Charge
variations.difference: Whiskey shot dropped directly into beer glass, then consumed immediately

variations.name: Craft Boilermaker
variations.difference: Use a craft beer (IPA, stout, etc.) and a complementary whiskey (bourbon, rye, Scotch) to create more nuanced flavours

tips: Use a light lager or ale if you want a milder beer‑chaser; stronger beers (IPA, stout) will increase bitterness and fullness.
Drink the whiskey first to appreciate its flavor before the beer washes it down.
If dropping the shot into the beer, ensure the beer glass is large enough to avoid overflow.
Chilling beer helps make the drink more refreshing and smooth.

healthProfile.notes: High alcohol content and moderate calories; minimal sugar

name: Hangman's Blood
drinkColor: Dark amber to deep brown with frothy top
warnings: Very high alcohol content — drink responsibly
instructions: Chill all ingredients (spirits, stout, champagne) beforehand.
Pour the gin, rum, whiskey, brandy, and port into a chilled pint glass (or large goblet).
Add the stout beer to the glass.
Carefully top up with chilled Champagne (or sparkling wine).
Serve immediately — no ice.
nameOrigin: Evocative, ominous name from literary origin
history: First described in the 1929 novel 'A High Wind in Jamaica' by Richard Hughes: initially as a mix of rum, gin, brandy and porter/beer. A later expanded version — attributed to Anthony Burgess — adds whiskey, port wine, stout, and tops with champagne.
funFacts: Originally a fictional drink from a 1929 novel.
Because of its many high-proof components, it’s considered one of the most potent beer cocktails.
Billed as 'refreshing as it tastes' in the original but infamous for 'demolishing the whole fort.'
tips: Use well-chilled stout and champagne to keep the drink more drinkable.
Pour stout first then top with champagne gently to reduce foaming.
Because it's extremely strong, sip slowly or consider sharing.

healthProfile.notes: Very high alcohol and calories — treat it as a sparing occasional indulgence.

name: Irish Car Bomb
warnings: Drink immediately after dropping shot – cream may curdle
instructions: Pour stout into a pint glass until about ¾ full.
In a shot glass, pour the Irish cream first, then layer the whiskey on top by pouring over the back of a spoon.
Drop the shot glass into the stout and drink immediately.
nameOrigin: Reference to 'bomb shot' style and Irish components
history: Invented in 1979 in Norwich, Connecticut by Charles Burke Cronin Oat, by dropping a shot of Irish cream + whiskey into a pint of stout. :contentReference[oaicite:6]{index=6}
funFacts: The drink must be consumed quickly because the cream will curdle when mixed with stout. :contentReference[oaicite:7]{index=7}
Due to sensitivities, many bartenders avoid using its original name in public menus. :contentReference[oaicite:8]{index=8}
tips: Drop the shot glass only when ready to drink — don’t let it sit.
Use cold stout for best experience.
Drink quickly to avoid curdling.

healthProfile.notes: High alcohol and moderate calories; not meant for slow sipping.

name: Michelada
instructions: Rub a lime wedge around the rim of a tall glass and dip the rim in salt mixed with chili powder or Tajín.
Fill the glass with ice if desired.
Add lime juice, Worcestershire sauce, and a few shakes of hot sauce.
Pour in the chilled beer slowly.
Stir gently and garnish with a lime wedge.
nameOrigin: From Mexican slang 'mi chela helada' meaning 'my cold beer' (chela = beer, helada = cold) :contentReference[oaicite:9]{index=9}
history: A traditional Mexican beer cocktail mixing beer with lime, spices, hot sauce and savory seasonings — popular as a refreshing and savory drink on hot days. :contentReference[oaicite:10]{index=10}
funFacts: Often described as the beer version of a Bloody Mary. :contentReference[oaicite:11]{index=11}
Glass is usually rimmed with salt and chili for extra flavor contrast. :contentReference[oaicite:12]{index=12}

variations.name: Clamato Michelada
variations.difference: Use Clamato (tomato + clam juice) or tomato juice for a richer, savory profile

tips: Chill the beer and ingredients before mixing for maximum refreshment
Adjust hot sauce, lime, and salt to your taste preference
Use a light lager for best balance

healthProfile.notes: Low in sugar and calories relative to many cocktails; refreshing option

name: Monaco
instructions: Pour grenadine into a chilled beer glass.
Slowly top up with equal parts cold beer and carbonated lemonade, tilting the glass to reduce foam.
Stir gently if needed and serve immediately.
nameOrigin: Named after the national colors of Monaco (red & white) — pink/red hue from grenadine over beer/lemonade mix. :contentReference[oaicite:13]{index=13}
history: A French beer cocktail mixing pale beer, lemonade, and a dash of grenadine — popular as a light, fruity drink for hot weather. :contentReference[oaicite:14]{index=14}
funFacts: Considered a sweeter, more playful alternative to straight beer or shandy. :contentReference[oaicite:15]{index=15}
tips: Use cold beer and chilled lemonade to maximize fizz and refreshment
Pour slowly to minimize foam
Adjust grenadine to control sweetness and color intensity

healthProfile.notes: Sweet and low‑alcohol; suitable for light sipping

name: Porchcrawler
drinkColor: Pale straw to yellow (depending on mix)
instructions: In a large cooler or pitcher, combine the lemonade concentrate and vodka (or gin).
Add cold water and stir to dilute.
Slowly pour in the chilled beer to avoid excessive foam.
Add ice to the container and garnish with lemon slices or berries before serving.
vibe: Casual, fun, and dangerously easy‑drinking party punch
nameOrigin: Implied reference to porch parties and crawling back home afterwards
history: Porchcrawler became popular among North American college students as a punch‑style beer + liquor + lemonade drink served in large batches from coolers. :contentReference[oaicite:16]{index=16}
funFacts: Also known as 'porchclimb'; often served out of a cooler at large gatherings. :contentReference[oaicite:17]{index=17}
Because of its high alcohol volume and sweet taste, it's deceptively strong. :contentReference[oaicite:18]{index=18}
tips: Add beer slowly after lemonade–spirit mix to avoid foam overflow
Keep mixture chilled before adding beer for best taste
Use light beer so lemonade flavour remains prominent

healthProfile.notes: High in alcohol, sugar and calories — treat as party punch

name: Queen Mary

garnishOptions.name: Maraschino cherry
garnishOptions.use: Drop into glass / rim or top foam

garnishOptions.name: Maraschino cherry syrup (optional)
garnishOptions.use: Drizzle on foam for extra sweetness

instructions: Pour grenadine into a chilled beer glass.
Slowly top up with cold beer, leaving some head space to let the foam form pink/red.
Garnish with maraschino cherry (or cherries) and optionally drizzle a little cherry syrup on the foam.
vibe: Sweet, fun, and easygoing beer mix
nameOrigin: Likely named to evoke regal‑style sweet beer cocktail
history: A simple blend of grenadine syrup and beer, often garnished with maraschino cherries — popular as an easy sweet beer‑cocktail. :contentReference[oaicite:19]{index=19}
funFacts: Works as a sweeter alternative to plain beer — sometimes called a 'gateway' beer cocktail. :contentReference[oaicite:20]{index=20}
tips: Chill beer before mixing for refreshing taste
Pour beer slowly to maintain foam and avoid overspill
Use light beer to let grenadine sweetness shine

healthProfile.notes: Low alcohol, but higher sugar than plain beer

name: Snakebite
instructions: Pour equal parts chilled lager and chilled hard apple cider into a pint glass.
Serve immediately without ice.
vibe: Crisp, easygoing, and slightly sweet pub‑style drink
nameOrigin: Likely a colourful name referencing the bite of the cider‑beer mix
history: Snakebite became popular in UK pubs in the 1980s as a straightforward mixture of equal parts lager and hard cider. :contentReference[oaicite:21]{index=21}
funFacts: Sometimes served with a dash of blackcurrant cordial — called 'Snakebite and Black' or 'Diesel'. :contentReference[oaicite:22]{index=22}

variations.name: Snakebite and Black
variations.difference: Add a splash of blackcurrant cordial for a sweeter, fruitier profile

tips: Use chilled beer and cider for best taste
Pour both slowly to reduce foam
Try with different ciders to vary sweetness and dryness

healthProfile.notes: Moderate alcohol and sugar — lighter than heavy cocktails but heavier than plain beer

name: Sake Bomb
drinkColor: Light amber beer with clear sake
warnings: Drink immediately after dropping the sake into beer
instructions: Pour chilled beer into a pint glass until half full.
Pour sake into a shot glass.
Place the shot glass on chopsticks over the beer glass and push it in to drop the shot into the beer.
Drink immediately.
nameOrigin: Refers to dropping a shot of sake into beer, 'bomb' style
history: Popularized in Japanese-American bars in the 1980s, combining sake and beer in a bomb-style cocktail. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sake_bomb?utm_source=chatgpt.com))
funFacts: Often used in social drinking games.
The chopsticks technique originated in Japanese-American bar culture.
tips: Drink immediately after dropping the shot to avoid flat beer.
Use cold beer and sake for best taste.

healthProfile.notes: Moderate calories, high alcohol — fast consumption increases intoxication risk.

name: Shandy
instructions: Fill a tall glass halfway with chilled beer.
Top up with lemonade to taste.
Garnish with a lemon slice and serve immediately.
nameOrigin: From Old English 'shandygaff', meaning beer mixed with ginger beer or lemonade
history: Shandy has long been a summer drink in the UK and Europe, mixing beer and lemonade or ginger beer for a light, refreshing beverage. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shandy?utm_source=chatgpt.com))
funFacts: Shandy is especially popular in Europe as a low-alcohol refreshment.
Modern versions include fruit-flavored sodas.

variations.name: Ginger Shandy
variations.difference: Use ginger beer instead of lemonade for a spicier flavor

tips: Use cold ingredients for best refreshment.
Adjust lemonade proportion for desired sweetness.

healthProfile.notes: Low-alcohol, light calories, refreshing summer drink.

name: Spaghett
instructions: Pour vodka into a shot glass.
Pour beer into a pint glass.
Drop the vodka shot into the beer and drink immediately.
nameOrigin: Possibly named after the Italian spaghetti-style long drink mixing method
history: Simple beer + vodka bomb shot cocktail popular in party settings.
funFacts: Similar to other 'bomb' style cocktails like Sake Bomb or Irish Car Bomb.
tips: Drink immediately after dropping the shot.
Use cold beer for smooth taste.

healthProfile.notes: High alcohol, moderate calories; intended for rapid consumption.

name: U-Boot
instructions: Pour chilled beer into a pint glass.
Pour vodka into a shot glass.
Drop the shot glass into the beer and drink immediately.
nameOrigin: U-Boot (submarine in German) due to the shot sinking in beer like a submarine
history: A traditional German bomb-style cocktail combining vodka and lager. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/U-Boot_(cocktail)?utm_source=chatgpt.com))
funFacts: Called 'Submarine' in some bars outside Germany.
Often used as a social drinking game drink.
tips: Drink immediately after dropping the shot.
Chill both beer and vodka for best taste.

healthProfile.notes: High alcohol; drink responsibly.

name: Angel Face
instructions: Pour all ingredients into a cocktail shaker filled with ice cubes.
Shake well until well chilled.
Strain into a chilled cocktail glass.
nameOrigin: First published in Harry Craddock’s 1930 The Savoy Cocktail Book; the name is believed to refer to its smooth, deceptively strong character or possibly to gangster Abe 'Angel Face' Reles
history: The Angel Face is an official IBA cocktail (The Unforgettables category) that debuted in Harry Craddock’s legendary 1930 The Savoy Cocktail Book. Equal parts of three spirits with no citrus or mixer, it is a perfect example of the early 20th-century style of simple, potent, fruit-brandy-based drinks.
funFacts: Contains no non-alcoholic ingredients — pure spirits
Sometimes nicknamed 'the liquid lunch'
Despite its innocent name, it’s one of the strongest IBA classics

variations.name: Modern Angel Face
variations.difference: Reduces apricot brandy to 15 ml and adds a dash of fresh lemon juice for balance

variations.name: Heavenly Face
variations.difference: Replaces gin with cognac for an all-brandy version

tips: Use a high-quality, dry London Dry gin to keep the drink balanced
Chill the glass thoroughly — this drink is best ice-cold
Use real apricot brandy liqueur (e.g., Marie Brizard Apry or Rothman & Winter), not apricot-flavored brandy

healthProfile.notes: 100% alcohol with significant sugar from liqueurs; high strength

name: Between the Sheets
instructions: Add all ingredients into a cocktail shaker filled with ice cubes.
Shake well until well chilled.
Strain into a chilled cocktail glass.
nameOrigin: Named for its provocative, potent nature, evoking a steamy encounter
history: Created in the 1920s at Harry's New York Bar in Paris by Harry MacElhone, this rum-spiked variation on the Sidecar became an IBA official cocktail, embodying the Roaring Twenties' spirit of indulgence.
funFacts: A cheeky twist on the Sidecar, replacing cognac partially with rum
Popular during Prohibition as an easy-to-smuggle drink

variations.name: Vintage Between the Sheets
variations.difference: Uses equal parts cognac and Jamaican rum for a bolder flavor

tips: Use Cointreau for a more refined orange note over generic triple sec
Shake vigorously to achieve a frothy texture
Garnish with a flame-kissed lemon twist for drama

healthProfile.notes: Balanced but potent; enjoy sparingly

name: Blow My Skull
warnings: Extremely strong; consume in small amounts
instructions: Stir sugar and boiling water in a large bowl to dissolve.
Add lime juice and stir.
Add porter, rum, and brandy; stir well.
Refrigerate until chilled.
Serve over ice in small cups; optionally flame for presentation.
nameOrigin: Named for its skull-blowing potency, invented by a notorious drinker
history: Invented by Tasmania's Lieutenant Governor Thomas Davey in the early 1800s, this punch from 'The English and Australian Cookery Book' (1864) evolved from Oceanic rum punches, gaining fame for its explosive strength among gold miners.
funFacts: Originally may have included opium in a 'Blow My Skull Off' variant
Revived in modern tiki culture as a flaming skull bowl punch

variations.name: Almost Blow My Skull Off
variations.difference: Uses cognac, peach schnapps, and Jägermeister for a modern twist

tips: Use a dark, robust porter for authentic maltiness
Adjust sugar to balance the lime's tartness
Serve small portions—it's deceptively strong

healthProfile.notes: High alcohol and calories; historical curiosity, not daily drink

name: Brandy Alexander
instructions: Add cognac, crème de cacao, and cream into a shaker with ice.
Shake until well-chilled.
Strain into a chilled cocktail glass.
Grate nutmeg over the top.
nameOrigin: Brandy variation of the original gin Alexander, named after its creator
history: Evolving from the 1916 gin-based Alexander at New York's Hotel Rector, the brandy version gained fame in the 1920s via Harry MacElhone, becoming a creamy IBA classic favored by celebrities like John Lennon.
funFacts: John Lennon's favorite cocktail; featured in his song 'Come Together'
Once a staple at white-tie dinners for its elegant, milky appearance

variations.name: Original Alexander
variations.difference: Substitutes gin for cognac

variations.name: Vodka Alexander
variations.difference: Uses vodka as the base for a lighter twist

tips: Use heavy cream for richest texture; half-and-half for lighter version
Dark crème de cacao adds depth; white for a subtler chocolate note
Dust with nutmeg just before serving to preserve aroma

healthProfile.notes: High in fat and sugar; best as an occasional treat

name: Brandy Crusta
instructions: Prepare the glass by coating the rim with lemon juice and dipping in sugar to create a crust.
Coil a lemon twist inside the glass.
Mix all ingredients with ice in a mixing glass.
Stir until well-chilled.
Strain into the prepared slim cocktail glass.
nameOrigin: Named for the signature sugar 'crusta' rim, a New Orleans innovation
history: Invented in 1850s New Orleans by Italian bartender Joseph Santini, this IBA classic was the fourth recipe in Jerry Thomas' 1862 'Bar-Tender's Guide,' predating and inspiring the Sidecar.
funFacts: Direct ancestor of the Sidecar and many modern sours
Revived in the 2000s by historian David Wondrich's 'Imbibe!'

variations.name: Whiskey Crusta
variations.difference: Substitutes rye whiskey for brandy

tips: Use a high-proof brandy for better balance against the citrus
The sugar crust is key—make it thick for tradition
Stir, don't shake, to preserve clarity

healthProfile.notes: Relatively low-cal for a classic; vitamin C from lemon

name: Brandy Old Fashioned
instructions: Place sugar cube in an old fashioned glass and dash with bitters.
Add orange slice and cherry, muddle lightly.
Add a splash of water or soda, then brandy.
Fill glass with ice cubes.
Top with lemon-lime soda.
Garnish with additional cherry and orange flag.
nameOrigin: Wisconsin’s twist on the classic Old Fashioned, replacing whiskey with brandy during Prohibition
history: Born in Wisconsin during the late 19th and early 20th centuries when German immigrants preferred brandy over whiskey. Korbel brandy shipments to the state skyrocketed, and the sweet, soda-topped version became the unofficial state cocktail.
funFacts: Wisconsin consumes more brandy per capita than any other U.S. state
Often ordered as 'sweet', 'sour', or 'press' (half soda, half seltzer)

variations.name: Brandy Old Fashioned Sour
variations.difference: Topped with Squirt or grapefruit soda instead of lemon-lime

variations.name: Brandy Old Fashioned Press
variations.difference: Topped with a mix of soda water and Sprite

tips: Use Korbel or another American brandy for authenticity
Muddle gently—don’t shred the fruit
Serve with a short straw and a long spoon for stirring

healthProfile.notes: High sugar from soda; classic indulgence

name: Brandy Manhattan
instructions: Add all ingredients into a mixing glass with ice cubes.
Stir well until chilled.
Strain into a chilled cocktail glass or over fresh ice in a rocks glass.
nameOrigin: A simple substitution of brandy for rye whiskey in the classic Manhattan
history: Popularized in the mid-20th century as an elegant alternative to the whiskey Manhattan, especially in regions with strong brandy traditions. Often called the 'Metropolitan' when made with a 3:1 brandy-to-vermouth ratio.
funFacts: Sometimes called the 'Harvard' or 'Metropolitan' in vintage bars
Frank Sinatra reportedly preferred a brandy Manhattan

variations.name: Perfect Brandy Manhattan
variations.difference: Uses 15 ml sweet and 15 ml dry vermouth, lemon twist garnish

tips: Use a good VSOP or XO cognac for richer flavor
Stir at least 30 seconds for proper dilution
Luxardo cherries elevate the drink significantly

healthProfile.notes: Lower sugar than many classics

name: Brandy Sour
instructions: Dry shake egg white (if using) vigorously.
Add all remaining ingredients with ice and shake hard.
Double strain into a chilled rocks glass over fresh ice.
Garnish with lemon wheel and cherry.
nameOrigin: Created as a covert way to serve brandy to King Farouk of Egypt in Cyprus
history: Invented in the 1930s at the Forest Park Hotel in Platres, Cyprus, to disguise brandy for Muslim King Farouk. Made with local lemon cordial and Angostura, it became the unofficial national drink of Cyprus.
funFacts: Cyprus Brandy Sour is protected by Cypriot law
Often made with local lemon squash instead of fresh juice

variations.name: Cyprus Brandy Sour
variations.difference: Uses lemon squash/cordial instead of fresh juice + syrup

tips: Dry shake vigorously for best foam
Use a rich, fruity brandy for authentic Cypriot style
Dash bitters on top of foam for aroma

healthProfile.notes: Vitamin C from lemon; raw egg risk if used

name: Chicago Cocktail
instructions: Rub lemon peel around rim of a wine glass.
Coat rim with fine sugar.
Add brandy, triple sec, and bitters to a mixing glass with ice.
Stir briefly.
Strain into prepared glass.

nameOrigin: Named after the windy city during its pre-Prohibition cocktail heyday
history: Appeared in early 20th-century cocktail books, a brandy-topped French 75 variant popular in Chicago speakeasies. The sugared rim and Champagne top make it a festive celebratory drink.
funFacts: One of the few classic cocktails that tops with sparkling wine
Sometimes made with ruby port floated on top in vintage recipes

Chill the sparkling wine thoroughly

name: Curaçao Punch

Extinguish flame before drinking

name: Diki-Diki
instructions: Add all ingredients into a shaker with ice.
Shake well until chilled.
Strain into a chilled cocktail glass.
nameOrigin: Named after a Filipino dictator’s nickname meaning “little boy”

name: Four Score

Strain into a chilled Nick & Nora or coupe glass.
Express orange oils over the drink.

name: French Connection

Serve without garnish.

history: Popularized in the 1970s after the Academy Award-winning film, this simple equal-parts drink became a staple digestif in discos and lounges. Its smooth almond-grape profile made it an easy sipper.
funFacts: One of the simplest classic cocktails—only two ingredients

Disaronno is traditional, but craft amari work well

name: Hennchata

Pour Hennessy and RumChata over the ice.

The combination of Hennessy (already a cultural icon) with the sweet, cinnamon horchata liqueur RumChata created an instant modern classic that requires zero skill and tastes like liquid cinnamon toast crunch.
funFacts: One of the fastest-spreading viral cocktails of the social-media era
Often referenced in rap lyrics and memes

variations.name: Vegan Hennchata
variations.difference: Use almond-milk based horchata liqueur

tips: Use crushed ice for faster chill and slight dilution
Hennessy VS is the traditional choice—VSOP for a smoother experience
Dust cinnamon right before serving so it floats

healthProfile.notes: Essentially alcoholic cinnamon milk—pure indulgence

name: Hoppel Poppel
instructions: Dry shake the whole egg vigorously for 15 seconds.
Add remaining ingredients with ice and shake hard.
Double strain into a chilled fizz or sour glass.
Grate fresh nutmeg over the foam.
nameOrigin: German-Yiddish term for a scrambled egg hash; applied to this egg-rich drink
history: Appeared in 1934 in 'The Old Waldorf-Astoria Bar Book' and later in Crosby Gaige’s 1940s guides. A rare whole-egg sour that predates the modern craft revival of egg drinks.
funFacts: One of the few classic cocktails that uses a whole egg (yolk + white)
Almost disappeared until revived by modern bartenders
tips: Dry shake hard—whole egg needs more agitation than just white
Use pasteurized egg if concerned about safety
Real apricot liqueur (not apricot-flavored brandy) is essential

healthProfile.notes: Protein from egg, but raw egg risk

name: Horse's Neck

garnishOptions.name: Lemon Peel Spiral
garnishOptions.use: Long spiral hanging over the rim like a horse’s neck

instructions: Peel a whole lemon in one continuous spiral.
Coil the peel inside a highball or collins glass, letting it hang over the rim.
Fill glass with ice cubes.
Pour brandy and top with chilled ginger ale.
Add bitters if desired, stir gently.
nameOrigin: The long lemon peel hanging over the glass resembles a horse’s neck
history: Started in the 1890s as a non-alcoholic ginger ale with lemon peel. By 1910, brandy (or bourbon) was added, turning it into one of the earliest highballs. Became an official IBA cocktail in The Unforgettables category.
funFacts: Originally a soft drink before spirits were added
Longest continuously listed cocktail in history

variations.name: Bourbon Horse’s Neck
variations.difference: Uses bourbon instead of brandy

tips: Use a good spicy ginger ale (Fever-Tree or Blenheim)
The lemon spiral is the star—practice your channel knife technique
Two dashes of Angostura make it a 'Horse’s Neck with a Kick'

healthProfile.notes: Relatively light and refreshing

name: Incredible Hulk
instructions: Fill a rocks glass with ice.
Pour equal parts Hennessy and Hpnotiq.
Stir gently—the clear liquids magically turn bright green.
nameOrigin: The drink turns bright green like Marvel’s Incredible Hulk
history: Invented in 2003 at a New York City Hpnotiq launch party when a bartender mixed it with Hennessy. The color-changing effect made it an instant hit in hip-hop clubs and appeared in countless music videos.
funFacts: The chemical reaction between Hpnotiq’s blue coloring and Hennessy’s amber creates the green color
Helped launch Hpnotiq into mainstream popularity

variations.name: Hulk Shot
variations.difference: Served as a layered shooter

tips: Chill both bottles beforehand for best color reaction
Never shake—stirring preserves the magic
Perfect 1:1 ratio is key

healthProfile.notes: Sugar bomb—pure party fuel

name: Jack Rose

ingredients.name: Applejack or Laird’s Bonded Apple Brandy

instructions: Add all ingredients into a shaker with ice.
Shake hard until well chilled.
Double strain into a chilled cocktail glass.
nameOrigin: Likely named after the gangster Jack Rose or the pink jacaranda flower
history: One of the six basic drinks in David A. Embury’s 1948 'The Fine Art of Mixing Drinks'. A flagship cocktail of American applejack during the early 20th century, it was the most popular applejack drink before Prohibition nearly killed the spirit.
funFacts: Helped keep Laird’s Apple Brandy in business during Prohibition
Featured in Hemingway’s 'The Sun Also Rises'

variations.name: Jersey Jack Rose
variations.difference: Uses lemon juice instead of lime

tips: Use Laird’s Bonded (100-proof) for authentic flavor and color
Homemade grenadine is essential—never rose’s sweetened lime
Shake vigorously to achieve a nice foam

healthProfile.notes: Real pomegranate antioxidants; relatively low calorie

name: Paradise
instructions: Add all ingredients into a shaker with ice.
Shake well until chilled.
Strain into a chilled cocktail glass.
nameOrigin: Evokes a taste of paradise with its apricot and citrus harmony
history: Official IBA cocktail from Harry Craddock’s 1930 Savoy Cocktail Book. One of the earliest gin-and-juice style drinks, it was a favorite in London during the interwar years.
funFacts: One of the few IBA classics that contains fresh orange juice
Precursor to many modern brunch cocktails
tips: Use a London Dry gin to let the apricot shine
Real apricot brandy liqueur (Marie Brizard Apry or Rothman & Winter) is crucial
Fresh-squeezed orange juice makes a huge difference

healthProfile.notes: Vitamin C from fresh juices

name: Pisco Sour
drinkColor: Pale cloudy green with white foam
instructions: Dry shake egg white vigorously.
Add pisco, lime juice, simple syrup, and ice; shake hard.
Double strain into a chilled old fashioned or Nick & Nora glass.
Dash Angostura bitters in a pattern on the foam.
vibe: Velvety, iconic, and proudly South American
nameOrigin: Pisco brandy + sour format
history: Invented around 1916–1920 by American expat Victor Morris in Lima, Peru. Refined by his bartender Mario Bruiget, it became Peru’s national drink and an IBA official cocktail. Chile also claims it, sparking a friendly rivalry.
funFacts: Peru has a national Pisco Sour Day (first Saturday of February)
The foam is so important it’s considered part of the garnish

variations.name: Chilean Pisco Sour
variations.difference: Uses Chilean pisco and sometimes lemon instead of lime

tips: Use Peruvian quebranta or acholado pisco for authenticity
Dry shake at least 15 seconds for perfect foam
Three artistic dashes of bitters are traditional

healthProfile.notes: Protein from egg white; vitamin C from lime

name: Porto Flip
instructions: Dry shake the whole egg vigorously.
Add port, brandy, syrup, and ice; shake hard.
Double strain into a chilled small port or cocktail glass.
Grate fresh nutmeg over the top.
nameOrigin: A flip made with port wine instead of usual spirits
history: Appears in Jerry Thomas’ 1862 book as a variation on the classic flip. Became an official IBA cocktail in the 20th century. Despite the name 'Coffee Cocktail' in some old books, it contains no coffee—only looks like one.
funFacts: One of the oldest documented flip styles
Was mistakenly called 'Coffee Cocktail' because of its color
tips: Use a rich ruby port for deeper flavor
Dry shake extra hard with whole egg
Serve in a small glass—rich and intense

healthProfile.notes: Protein from egg; high sugar from port

name: Savoy Affair
instructions: Shake cognac, strawberry liqueur, banana liqueur, and lime juice with ice.
Strain into a chilled flute or coupe.
Top carefully with chilled Champagne.
Garnish with a fresh strawberry.
nameOrigin: Created at The Savoy Hotel, London – an “affair” of luxurious ingredients
history: Published in Harry Craddock’s 1930 The Savoy Cocktail Book. A rare sparkling cocktail from the golden age that combines cognac with strawberry and banana liqueurs – a decadent celebration drink from one of the world’s most famous hotel bars.
funFacts: One of the few Savoy originals that tops with Champagne
Almost disappeared until the 2010s craft revival
tips: Use Giffard Crème de Fraise des Bois for authentic wild-strawberry flavor
Chill the Champagne thoroughly to preserve bubbles
Pour the sparkling wine slowly to avoid overflow

healthProfile.notes: Celebratory treat with fresh fruit notes

name: Savoy Corpse Reviver
warnings: Harry Craddock warned: 'Four taken in quick succession will unrevive the corpse again'
instructions: Rinse a chilled coupe with absinthe and discard excess.
Add all remaining ingredients to a shaker with ice.
Shake hard and double strain into the absinthe-rinsed glass.
Express lemon zest over surface and discard.
vibe: Legendary hangover cure with mythical status
nameOrigin: Corpse Reviver family of pre-Prohibition pick-me-ups; No.2 is the famous Savoy version
history: The definitive version published in The Savoy Cocktail Book (1930) by Harry Craddock. Widely considered one of the greatest cocktails ever created and the only Corpse Reviver still regularly served. IBA official in The Unforgettables.
funFacts: Frank Meier at the Paris Ritz claimed he invented it earlier
Considered the benchmark by which all modern cocktails are judged

variations.name: Corpse Reviver No.1
variations.difference: Uses cognac, calvados, sweet vermouth – served up, no absinthe

tips: Equal parts (except absinthe) is non-negotiable
Cocchi Americano or modern Lillet with quinine is closer to the 1930 original
Never skip the absinthe rinse – it makes the drink

healthProfile.notes: Vitamin C from lemon; legendary restorative

name: Sazerac

ingredients.name: Cognac or Rye Whiskey (original used Cognac)

instructions: Chill an old fashioned glass in the freezer.
In a mixing glass, muddle sugar cube with water and Peychaud’s bitters.
Add cognac and ice, stir until well chilled.
Rinse the chilled glass with absinthe and discard excess.
Strain the drink into the prepared glass.
Express lemon peel oils over surface and discard peel.
nameOrigin: Named after Sazerac de Forge et Fils cognac, the original base spirit
history: Created circa 1850 in New Orleans using Sazerac cognac and Peychaud’s bitters. The phylloxera epidemic forced a switch to rye in the 1870s, but the original was cognac-based. Declared the official cocktail of New Orleans in 2008. IBA official.
funFacts: Widely considered America’s first cocktail
Originally served in an egg-shaped coquetier glass – possible origin of the word 'cocktail'

variations.name: Rye Sazerac
variations.difference: Modern version using rye whiskey instead of cognac

tips: Use a good VSOP cognac for historical accuracy
Two glasses method (one for mixing, one for rinsing) is traditional
Never drop the lemon peel in – only express and discard

healthProfile.notes: Minimal sugar, high proof – pure spirit enjoyment

name: Sidecar
instructions: Optionally sugar-rim a chilled coupe.
Add all ingredients to a shaker with ice.
Shake hard until well chilled.
Double strain into the prepared glass.
Express orange peel over surface.
nameOrigin: Named after a patron who arrived at the bar in a motorcycle sidecar
history: Born during World War I in Paris or London (Harry’s New York Bar and The Ritz both claim it). First printed in 1922. The perfect balance of spirit, citrus, and orange liqueur – considered one of the greatest cocktails ever created. Official IBA Unforgettables.
funFacts: The only cocktail with two competing origin cities – Paris and London
Ratio debate (2:1:1 vs 3:2:1) has raged for a century

variations.name: Boston Sidecar
variations.difference: Adds rum and uses lime juice

variations.name: Chelsea Sidecar
variations.difference: Uses gin instead of cognac

tips: Use VSOP cognac and Cointreau for best results
The French school uses 2:1:1 ratio; American prefers 3:2:1
Sugar rim is optional but traditional in many bars

healthProfile.notes: Vitamin C from fresh lemon

name: Singapore Sling
instructions: Pour all ingredients except soda into a shaker with ice.
Shake well.
Strain into a tall highball or hurricane glass filled with ice.
Top with soda water.
Garnish lavishly with pineapple and cherry.
nameOrigin: Created at the Long Bar of Raffles Hotel, Singapore – originally disguised as a “fruit punch” for ladies
history: Invented by bartender Ngiam Tong Boon at Raffles Hotel’s Long Bar around 1915. Originally a pink gin sling for women to drink discreetly in public. The exact original recipe was lost until rediscovered in 2010s hotel archives. Official IBA Unforgettables cocktail.
funFacts: Peanuts are traditionally served at the Long Bar so guests throw shells on the floor
Over 1 million Singapore Slings are served at Raffles every year

variations.name: Straits Sling
variations.difference: Omits pineapple juice and soda, uses dry cherry brandy

tips: Use Cherry Heering, not generic cherry brandy
Fresh pineapple juice is non-negotiable
The Raffles original is slightly less sweet than most bar versions

healthProfile.notes: Vitamin C from pineapple and lime

name: Stinger
drinkColor: Clear pale green (with white crème de menthe)
instructions: Add cognac and crème de menthe to a mixing glass with ice.
Stir until well chilled.
Strain into a chilled cocktail glass or over crushed ice in a rocks glass.
nameOrigin: The minty kick “stings” the palate like a bee
history: One of the oldest known cocktails featuring crème de menthe. Popular among American high society and billionaires like Reginald Vanderbilt in the early 20th century. Became the signature drink of the 1950s–60s jet set. Official IBA Unforgettables.
funFacts: James Bond orders a Stinger in two Ian Fleming novels
Was considered a 'manly' mint drink before mint cocktails became sweet

variations.name: Vodka Stinger
variations.difference: Substitutes vodka for cognac – more common today

tips: Use white crème de menthe – green is artificial
Serve up in a coupe for elegance or crushed ice for refreshment
Use a good VSOP or XO cognac – it’s half the drink

healthProfile.notes: Pure liqueur + spirit indulgence

name: The Blenheim
instructions: Stir all ingredients with ice until perfectly chilled.
Strain into a chilled Nick & Nora or coupe glass.
Express orange oils over the surface.
nameOrigin: Named after Blenheim Palace, birthplace of Winston Churchill
history: Created in 2010 by Erik Lorincz at the American Bar, Savoy Hotel, London. A modern masterpiece that bridges classic cognac tradition with herbal complexity. Quickly became a contemporary classic in top bars worldwide.
funFacts: Won multiple international cocktail awards
Yellow Chartreuse is the star – use Green and it becomes a different drink
tips: Stir for at least 40 seconds – dilution is crucial
Use a high-quality VSOP cognac
Regans’ or Fee Brothers orange bitters work best

healthProfile.notes: Herbal digestif properties

name: Tom and Jerry
instructions: Prepare batter in advance: beat egg whites to stiff peaks, beat yolks with sugar and spices, fold together.
Add 2 tbsp batter to a preheated mug.
Pour in cognac and rum.
Top with hot milk or water while stirring vigorously.
Grate fresh nutmeg on top.
glassType: Tom & Jerry mug or Irish coffee mug
nameOrigin: Named after the bartender’s alter egos or the famous cat-and-mouse cartoon (debated)
history: First published by Jerry Thomas in 1862. A holiday staple across the American Midwest for over a century, served in punch bowls at Christmas parties. The batter is prepared in advance and served hot with cognac and rum.
funFacts: Was the original American holiday punch before eggnog dominated
Special Tom & Jerry bowl sets were common wedding gifts in the 1940s–50s

variations.name: Rum Tom and Jerry
variations.difference: Omits cognac, doubles rum

tips: Make batter the day before for best texture
Use boiling water if you want a lighter version
Keep batter refrigerated and serve within 24 hours

healthProfile.notes: Rich holiday indulgence; raw egg risk

name: 20th Century Cocktail
instructions: Add all ingredients to a shaker filled with ice.
Shake hard until well chilled (about 12–15 seconds).
Double strain into a chilled Nick & Nora or coupe glass.
Express a lemon twist over the surface and discard (or drop in).
vibe: Elegant 1930s luxury liner in a glass
nameOrigin: Named after the famous 20th Century Limited luxury train that ran from New York to Chicago 1902–1967 – the cocktail was created to honor its glamour
history: First published in 1937 by British bartender C. A. Tuck in the Café Royal Cocktail Book (Coronation Edition). Rediscovered in the early 2000s by modern cocktail historians, it quickly became a craft-bar darling for its astonishing balance of gin and chocolate. Often called “the chocolate martini that actually works.”
funFacts: One of the very few classic cocktails that successfully pairs gin with chocolate
The original 20th Century Limited train had a red-carpet rollout in Grand Central – passengers felt like movie stars
Lillet Blanc in the 1930s had more quinine than today – many modern recipes add a dash of quinine or use Cocchi Americano for historical accuracy

variations.name: 21st Century Cocktail
variations.difference: Adds a barspoon of absinthe and uses Cocchi Americano instead of Lillet

tips: Use a high-quality white crème de cacao (Tempus Fugit or Giffard) – cheap ones taste like cheap chocolate syrup
A London Dry gin with strong juniper (Tanqueray, Beefeater, or Sipsmith V.J.O.P.) stands up best to the chocolate
Shake vigorously – the lemon juice needs full aeration to balance the richness
If you want it closer to the 1930s original, substitute half the Lillet with Cocchi Americano for extra quinine bite

healthProfile.notes: Moderate sugar; small vitamin C hit from fresh lemon

name: Aviation
warnings: Crème de violette can dominate if overpoured
instructions: Add all ingredients to a cocktail shaker
Fill with ice and shake vigorously for 12–15 seconds
Double-strain into a chilled coupe glass
Garnish with a brandied cherry
nameOrigin: Named after the glamorous new era of aviation; the violet hue evokes the sky at twilight
history: Created in 1916 by Hugo Ensslin, head bartender at the Hotel Wallick in New York, and published in his book Recipes for Mixed Drinks. The drink nearly vanished during Prohibition when crème de violette disappeared from the market. It was revived in the early 2000s when Rothman & Winter reintroduced crème de violette.
funFacts: One of the very last classic cocktails created before U.S. Prohibition
Harry Craddock’s 1930 Savoy Cocktail Book omitted the violette, causing decades of pale versions
Considered a flagship drink of the modern craft-cocktail revival

variations.name: Blue Moon
variations.difference: Omits maraschino liqueur and increases crème de violette for deeper color and flavor

variations.name: Modern Aviation
variations.difference: Reduces crème de violette to 7–8 ml for a subtler floral note

tips: Use a classic London Dry gin; overly botanical gins clash with the violette
Measure the crème de violette carefully – too much tastes like perfume
Always double-strain for a crystal-clear appearance
Luxardo or Fabbri brandied cherries are the traditional garnish

healthProfile.notes: Contains moderate sugar from liqueurs and relatively high alcohol content

name: Bee's Knees
warnings: Contains honey – not suitable for vegans
Can be cloying if honey syrup is too thick

garnishOptions.name: Lemon twist
garnishOptions.use: Express over drink and discard or place on rim

instructions: Combine gin, fresh lemon juice, and honey syrup in a cocktail shaker
Add plenty of ice and shake vigorously for 12–15 seconds (honey needs extra agitation to integrate)
Double-strain into a chilled coupe or Nick & Nora glass
Express a lemon or orange twist over the surface and garnish
nameOrigin: 1920s American slang meaning 'the best' or 'the height of excellence'
history: Created during American Prohibition (likely by Frank Meier at the Ritz Hotel in Paris, or possibly in the U.S.) to mask the harsh taste of poor-quality 'bathtub' gin. The strong lemon and honey effectively covered inferior spirits while creating a delicious drink in its own right. It became one of the iconic Prohibition-era cocktails.
funFacts: The phrase 'bee’s knees' was 1920s flapper slang for something outstanding
Honey and citrus were classic bathtub-gin disguisers during Prohibition
Experienced a major revival in the 2000s craft cocktail movement

variations.name: Honey Bee
variations.difference: Uses 3:1 honey syrup for a richer, sweeter profile

variations.name: Lavender Bee’s Knees
variations.difference: Infuses honey syrup with dried lavender for floral depth

variations.name: Gin Daisy variation
variations.difference: Adds a splash of soda water and serves over crushed ice

tips: Always use 2:1 or 3:1 honey syrup – raw honey alone will not dissolve properly in a cold drink
Shake extra hard to fully emulsify the honey syrup
A floral gin (Hendrick’s, Aviation) works beautifully, but classic London Dry is traditional
Fresh lemon juice is non-negotiable

healthProfile.notes: Higher natural sugar content from honey; moderate calories

name: Bijou
drinkColor: Deep ruby red with golden highlights

garnishOptions.name: Lemon twist
garnishOptions.use: Express oils and discard or place on rim

instructions: Add all ingredients to a mixing glass
Fill with ice and stir smoothly for 20–30 seconds until well-chilled
Strain into a chilled Nick & Nora or small coupe glass
Garnish with a brandied cherry (traditional) or lemon twist
nameOrigin: French for 'jewel' – the three main ingredients were said to represent diamond (gin), ruby (sweet vermouth), and emerald (green Chartreuse)
history: Created by legendary bartender Harry Johnson and first published in his 1900 edition of the 'Bartender’s Manual'. One of the earliest equal-parts cocktails, it was extremely popular in the late 19th and early 20th centuries but faded during Prohibition and the mid-century due to Chartreuse scarcity. Rediscovered during the craft cocktail revival.
funFacts: One of the oldest named cocktails on record using Chartreuse
The original recipe called for Grand Marnier in some versions, but green Chartreuse became standard
Considered a direct ancestor of the modern Last Word cocktail

variations.name: Emerald Bijou
variations.difference: Uses yellow Chartreuse instead of green for a lighter, more citrus-forward profile

variations.name: Modern Bijou
variations.difference: Adjusts ratios to 45 ml gin, 22.5 ml each Chartreuse and vermouth for a drier drink

tips: Use a high-quality sweet vermouth (Carpano Antica, Cocchi Torino, or Dolin Rouge)
Stir gently but thoroughly – over-dilution kills the richness
A single Luxardo cherry is the classic garnish
Perfect winter warmer despite being served up

healthProfile.notes: Very high alcohol content, low sugar but rich in herbal liqueurs

name: Bramble
instructions: Shake gin, lemon juice, and simple syrup with ice
Strain into an Old-Fashioned glass filled with crushed ice
Drizzle crème de mûre over the top so it bleeds down
Garnish with fresh blackberries and optionally a lemon wheel
nameOrigin: Named after the bramble bush on which blackberries grow
history: Created in 1984 by legendary London bartender Dick Bradsell at Fred’s Club in Soho. Intended as a distinctly British answer to the Singapore Sling, using seasonal British blackberries.
funFacts: Dick Bradsell also created the Espresso Martini
The float of crème de mûre creates the signature bleeding effect

variations.name: English Garden Bramble
variations.difference: Muddle fresh cucumber before shaking

variations.name: Winter Bramble
variations.difference: Uses sloe gin and blackberry-sage syrup

tips: Use very fresh, ripe blackberries for garnish
Don’t shake the crème de mûre – always drizzle last
A richer 2:1 simple syrup works well if you prefer sweeter

healthProfile.notes: Fresh fruit helps, but still sugary

name: Bronx
instructions: Add all ingredients to a shaker with ice
Shake hard for 12–15 seconds (to aerate the orange juice)
Double-strain into a chilled coupe or martini glass
Garnish with an orange twist
nameOrigin: Named after the newly opened Bronx Zoo (1906) – one of the first cocktails named after a New York borough
history: Created around 1906 at the Waldorf-Astoria in Manhattan. For a brief period in the 1920s–30s it reportedly outsold the Martini in New York.
funFacts: Once claimed to be the third-most popular cocktail in the world (1930s)
Considered the first cocktail to use fruit juice in a big way

variations.name: Bronx Golden
variations.difference: Uses only sweet vermouth and adds an egg yolk

variations.name: Income Tax Cocktail
variations.difference: Adds 2 dashes Angostura bitters

tips: Fresh-squeezed orange juice is essential – never carton
Shake vigorously to create a nice froth
A 2:1:1:2 ratio is the most common modern spec

healthProfile.notes: Contains real fruit juice but still alcoholic

name: Casino
instructions: Add all ingredients to a shaker with ice
Shake well and fine-strain into a chilled coupe
Garnish with a brandied cherry
nameOrigin: Likely named after the glamour of European casinos
history: First printed in Harry Craddock’s 1930 Savoy Cocktail Book. Considered an improvement on the Aviation by removing the violette and adding bitters.
funFacts: Often called 'Aviation without the violette'
Old Tom gin is historically correct and gives rounder sweetness

variations.name: Aviation
variations.difference: Adds crème de violette

variations.name: Alaska
variations.difference: Uses yellow Chartreuse instead of maraschino

tips: Old Tom gin (Hayman’s or Ransom) is traditional and preferred
Use real Luxardo maraschino – not cheap cherry liqueur
2 dashes of orange bitters is key to balance

healthProfile.notes: Low sugar but strong alcohol

name: Clover Club
warnings: Contains raw egg white – not suitable for vulnerable groups
instructions: Dry shake (no ice) all ingredients for 10–15 seconds
Add ice and shake hard again for 10 seconds
Double-strain into a chilled coupe
Garnish with 3 speared raspberries
garnish: Three fresh raspberries on a skewer
nameOrigin: Named after the Philadelphia men’s club ‘Clover Club’ that met at the Bellevue-Stratford Hotel
history: Pre-Prohibition Philadelphia classic named after a gentlemen’s club of lawyers and writers. Nearly disappeared mid-century but revived in the 2000s craft movement.
funFacts: One of the earliest widely popular egg-white cocktails
Originally made with fresh muddled raspberries

variations.name: Clover Leaf
variations.difference: Adds fresh mint leaves

variations.name: Vegan Clover Club
variations.difference: Uses aquafaba instead of egg white

tips: Dry shake vigorously to get maximum foam
Homemade raspberry syrup (2:1 sugar:raspberries) is far superior to commercial
London Dry or slightly floral gin works best

healthProfile.notes: Contains raw egg white and fruit sugar

name: Corpse Reviver #2
warnings: Harry Craddock famously wrote: 'Four of these taken in swift succession will unrevive the corpse again.'
instructions: Rinse a chilled coupe with absinthe and discard excess
Add gin, Lillet, Cointreau, and lemon juice to a shaker with ice
Shake hard for 10–12 seconds
Fine-strain into the absinthe-rinsed coupe
Garnish with a brandied cherry (traditional)
nameOrigin: Part of a family of 'Corpse Reviver' hair-of-the-dog cocktails; #2 is the only one that survived
history: Published in Harry Craddock’s 1930 Savoy Cocktail Book. Intended as a morning-after restorative. The #1 version (cognac, Calvados, sweet vermouth) has largely been forgotten.
funFacts: Considered one of the finest cocktails ever created
Equal-parts recipe makes it one of the easiest classics to remember
Modern versions sometimes substitute Cocchi Americano for Lillet Blanc to match the original pre-1986 Lillet flavour

variations.name: Corpse Reviver #2 (Cocchi version)
variations.difference: Uses Cocchi Americano instead of Lillet for a more bitter, quinine-forward profile

variations.name: Naked & Famous
variations.difference: Modern riff using mezcal, yellow Chartreuse, Aperol, and lime

tips: Use only a dash or rinse of absinthe – too much ruins the balance
Fresh lemon juice is critical
The drink should be ice-cold and crystal clear

healthProfile.notes: Strong and spirit-forward despite the citrus

name: French 75

garnishOptions.name: Lemon twist
garnishOptions.use: Long spiral in glass or on rim

instructions: Shake gin, lemon juice, and simple syrup with ice
Fine-strain into a chilled flute
Top with chilled champagne
Garnish with a long lemon twist
nameOrigin: Named after the French 75mm field gun used in WWI – said to have similar kick
history: Created at Harry’s New York Bar in Paris during World War I. Originally made with cognac, but the gin version became dominant by the 1920s–30s.
funFacts: Appeared in the 1942 film Casablanca
The original 1915 recipe used cognac, but gin version won

variations.name: French 76
variations.difference: Uses vodka instead of gin

variations.name: French 77
variations.difference: Adds elderflower liqueur and tops with champagne

tips: Use good champagne – cheap sparkling kills the drink
Chill the flute and all ingredients
Some modern versions use 30 ml gin for lighter feel

healthProfile.notes: Bubbly and refreshing but still alcoholic

name: Gimlet
instructions: Shake all ingredients with ice
Fine-strain into a chilled coupe or over ice in a rocks glass
Garnish with a lime wheel
nameOrigin: Possibly named after British naval surgeon Sir Thomas Gimlette or the tool used to tap barrels
history: Originated in the British Royal Navy to prevent scurvy using Rose’s Lime Cordial. Raymond Chandler immortalised the modern fresh-lime version in The Long Goodbye (1953).
funFacts: Raymond Chandler’s Philip Marlowe drinks gimlets
Originally made with Rose’s Lime Cordial only – fresh lime version is post-WWII

variations.name: Vodka Gimlet
variations.difference: Substitutes vodka for gin

variations.name: Basil Gimlet
variations.difference: Muddled basil leaves added

tips: 2:1 gin-to-lime ratio is modern standard (some prefer 3:1 or 4:1)
Fresh lime juice + simple is vastly superior to Rose’s cordial
Plymouth or Navy Strength gin works beautifully

healthProfile.notes: Simple and relatively low sugar

name: Gin and Tonic

garnishOptions.name: Botanical garnishes (juniper berries, rosemary, cucumber, etc.)

instructions: Fill a highball or Spanish copa glass with ice
Pour gin over ice
Top with chilled tonic water
Squeeze lime wedge and drop in
Stir gently once
vibe: The world’s most popular gin drink – simple perfection
nameOrigin: Created by British officers in India to make quinine (anti-malaria) palatable
history: Born in colonial India when British officers mixed their medicinal quinine tonic with gin. Exploded in popularity worldwide in the 20th century. The Spanish revived it as a gourmet drink in the 2000s.
funFacts: Responsible for the entire craft gin boom
Spain serves the largest, most garnished G&Ts in huge balloon glasses

variations.name: Spanish Gin Tonics
variations.difference: Huge glass, lots of ice, elaborate botanical garnishes

variations.name: Gin Sonic
variations.difference: Half tonic, half soda water for lighter feel

tips: Quality ice and premium tonic are everything

name: Gin Fizz

name: Negroni

garnishOptions.use: Express oils and place on rim

name: Ramos Gin Fizz

Serve straight up – no ice
vibe: Stiff upper lip in liquid form
nameOrigin: Angostura bitters turn gin pink
history: Invented by Royal Navy officers in the 19th century as a remedy for seasickness. Angostura was believed to settle the stomach. Became the traditional drink of the Senior Service.
funFacts: No mixer – just gin and bitters
One of the few cocktails that is traditionally served at room temperature

variations.name: Pink Gin & Tonic
variations.difference: Add tonic water for a gentler version

tips: Use a well-chilled glass and gin straight from the freezer
Adjust bitters to taste – traditional is 4–8 dashes
Never add ice to the served drink

healthProfile.notes: Zero sugar, zero carbs – just pure spirit and bitters

name: Pink Lady
instructions: Add all ingredients to shaker
Dry shake vigorously without ice for 15 seconds
Add ice and shake again until well chilled
Double strain into chilled coupe
Garnish with cherry
vibe: Playful sophistication with a frothy crown
nameOrigin: Its delicate pink color and frothy texture
history: Popular during Prohibition and into the 1940s–50s. An IBA official cocktail. Often associated with high society and Broadway glamour.
funFacts: Joan Crawford claimed it was her favorite drink
Was-worthy froth comes from the egg white

variations.name: Clover Club
variations.difference: Uses raspberry syrup instead of grenadine

variations.name: Pink Lady Royale
variations.difference: Top with champagne after straining

tips: Dry shake is essential for maximum foam
Use real pomegranate grenadine
Pasteurized egg white for safety

healthProfile.notes: Contains raw egg white; high sugar from grenadine

name: Queens
instructions: Blend all ingredients with crushed ice until smooth
Pour into a chilled large cocktail or hurricane glass
Garnish with pineapple and cherry
nameOrigin: Named in honor of Queen Mary (wife of George V)
history: Appeared in 1934 cocktail books during the reign of George V. A frozen variation using both sweet and dry vermouth with pineapple – rare for its era.
funFacts: One of the earliest frozen cocktails on record
Uses equal parts sweet and dry vermouth – a Perfect base

variations.name: King’s Queens
variations.difference: Add a dash of Angostura bitters and serve on rocks

tips: Use fresh pineapple juice if possible
Blend until completely smooth and frothy
Don’t skimp on ice – texture is key

healthProfile.notes: Pineapple juice adds vitamin C; moderate alcohol

name: Royal Arrival
instructions: Shake gin, crème de violette, lemon juice, and simple syrup with ice
Double strain into a chilled flute or coupe
Top slowly with chilled champagne
Garnish with a violet flower or lemon twist
nameOrigin: Created for the arrival of royal babies and weddings in the 2010s
history: A modern gin-champagne cocktail that gained fame during the weddings of Prince William (2011) and Prince Harry (2018). An elegant variation on the Aviation topped with bubbles.
funFacts: Served at many royal-wedding watch parties
The violet liqueur gives it a delicate purple tint

variations.name: Royal Departure
variations.difference: Add a dash of absinthe and serve in a coupe without top-up

tips: Chill the champagne flute in advance
Pour champagne slowly to preserve bubbles
Use Rothman & Winter or The Bitter Truth crème de violette

healthProfile.notes: Contains champagne and liqueur sugars

name: Salty Dog
instructions: Rim a highball glass with salt
Fill glass with ice cubes
Pour gin and grapefruit juice
Stir gently
Garnish with grapefruit wedge
nameOrigin: The salted rim – same drink without salt is a Greyhound
history: An IBA official cocktail. Emerged in the 1950s as a simple highball; the gin version predates the more common vodka variant.
funFacts: Without the salted rim it’s simply called a Greyhound
Popular breakfast/brunch drink in the U.S.

variations.name: Vodka Salty Dog
variations.difference: Substitute vodka for gin

tips: Always use fresh grapefruit juice
Pink or ruby red grapefruit gives the prettiest color
Salt only half the rim if guests are unsure

healthProfile.notes: High vitamin C from fresh grapefruit

name: Suffering Bastard
instructions: Fill a tall glass or tiki mug with ice
Add gin, bourbon, lime juice, and bitters
Top with ginger beer
Stir gently
Garnish with mint and orange
nameOrigin: Created to cure hungover British officers in Cairo during WWII
history: Invented in 1942 by Joe Scialom at the Shepheard’s Hotel, Cairo, as a hangover cure for Allied troops. Originally made with imported gin and brandy plus locally brewed ginger beer.
funFacts: Originally contained brandy instead of bourbon
Joe Scialom could mix eight at a time – one in each hand plus teeth

variations.name: Dying Bastard
variations.difference: Add rum to make it a three-spirit drink

variations.name: Dead Bastard
variations.difference: Add rum, brandy, and bourbon with the gin

tips: Use a spicy ginger beer (not ginger ale)
Slap the mint to release oils
Double the recipe if you’re really suffering

healthProfile.notes: Ginger aids digestion; high alcohol

name: Takumi’s Aviation

ingredients.name: Japanese Gin (Roku or Ki No Bi)
Crème Yvette or Crème de Violette
Sakura Liqueur or Cherry Blossom Syrup

instructions: Add all ingredients to a shaker with ice
Shake hard for 12–15 seconds
Double strain into a chilled coupe
Garnish with a brandied cherry and/or sakura petal
nameOrigin: Modern twist on the classic Aviation by award-winning Japanese bartender Takumi Watanabe
history: Created by Takumi Watanabe (head bartender of The SG Club, Tokyo) as a Japanese interpretation of the pre-Prohibition Aviation, incorporating local gin and sakura elements.
funFacts: Uses Japanese craft gin with yuzu, sansho, and sakura
Won multiple awards in Asia Bar Awards

variations.name: Classic Aviation
variations.difference: Omit sakura, use standard gin and slightly more crème de violette

tips: Roku or Ki No Bi are ideal – their botanicals complement sakura
Balance the violette carefully; it can overpower
Serve ice-cold

healthProfile.notes: Liqueur-heavy but beautifully balanced

name: Tom Collins

ingredients.name: Old Tom Gin or London Dry Gin

instructions: Add gin, lemon juice and simple syrup to a Collins glass filled with ice
Top with soda water
Stir gently
Garnish with lemon wheel and cherry
nameOrigin: Named after the “Great Tom Collins Hoax” of 1874
history: First published in Jerry Thomas’ 1876 bartending guide. Rose to fame after the 1874 New York prank where people were told a mysterious “Tom Collins” was bad-mouthing them – leading them to bars asking for the drink.
funFacts: One of the oldest documented gin cocktails
The hoax made it famous nationwide

variations.name: Vodka Collins
variations.difference: Vodka instead of gin

variations.name: Juan Collins
variations.difference: Tequila instead of gin

tips: Use Old Tom gin for historical accuracy
Fresh lemon juice is essential
Build in glass – no shaking required

healthProfile.notes: High vitamin C from fresh lemon

name: Tuxedo

ingredients.name: Old Tom Gin or London Dry Gin

instructions: Stir all ingredients with ice in mixing glass
Strain into chilled cocktail glass
Express lemon twist over surface and garnish
nameOrigin: Named after the Tuxedo Club in New York where the tuxedo jacket was popularized
history: Born around 1900 at the Tuxedo Club, New York. A refined variation of the Martini with absinthe and maraschino.
funFacts: One of the earliest documented Martini variations
The tuxedo jacket was invented at the same club

variations.name: Tuxedo No. 1
variations.difference: Uses equal parts gin and sherry instead of vermouth

tips: Rinse glass with absinthe for subtler anise note
Use Old Tom gin for a softer, sweeter profile

healthProfile.notes: Very low sugar and carbs

name: Vesper
instructions: Pour all ingredients into a deep champagne goblet or cocktail shaker
Shake very well with plenty of ice until ice-cold
Strain into a chilled deep champagne goblet or large cocktail glass
Express a large thin-cut lemon peel over the surface
nameOrigin: Named after Vesper Lynd, Bond’s love interest in Casino Royale
history: First appeared in Ian Fleming’s 1953 novel Casino Royale. Bond invents and names the drink after double-agent Vesper Lynd.
funFacts: Bond’s exact words: “Three measures of Gordon’s, one of vodka, half a measure of Kina Lillet. Shake it very well until it’s ice-cold, then add a large thin slice of lemon peel.”
Originally used Kina Lillet (now replaced by Lillet Blanc or Cocchi Americano)

variations.name: Vesper (Modern)
variations.difference: Reduce gin to 60 ml for balance

tips: Use 100-proof vodka if possible – as Bond specified
Shake hard – Bond insisted on shaken
Original Kina Lillet was more bitter; add a dash of quinine if desired

healthProfile.notes: Very high alcohol content

name: White Lady
instructions: Dry shake all ingredients without ice for 10–15 seconds
Add ice and shake hard again
Double strain into chilled coupe
Express lemon twist over the frothy top
nameOrigin: Its pale, elegant appearance
history: Final version perfected by Harry MacElhone at Harry’s New York Bar, Paris in 1929. Earlier versions by Harry Craddock (1923) and others used crème de menthe.
funFacts: An IBA official cocktail
Sometimes called the “gin Sidecar with egg white”

variations.name: Blue Lady
variations.difference: Use blue curaçao instead of Cointreau

tips: Dry shake is crucial for the signature frothy cap
Use Cointreau for the best orange flavor
Pasteurized egg white or aquafaba for safety

healthProfile.notes: Contains raw egg white; moderate sugar from liqueur

name: Wolfram
instructions: Stir all ingredients with plenty of ice
Strain into a chilled Nick & Nora or coupe glass
Express orange peel over surface
nameOrigin: Named after the chemical element tungsten (atomic symbol W) – known for being heavy, dense, and extremely tough
history: A modern bitter-heavy gin cocktail that emerged in the 2010s craft cocktail scene, popular among bartenders who love intense amaro combinations.
funFacts: Contains four different bitter/herbal elements
Not for the faint of palate

variations.name: Wolfram Light
variations.difference: Reduce Suze and Montenegro by half

tips: Stir for at least 30 seconds for proper dilution
All ingredients are crucial – no substitutions
Best served ice-cold

healthProfile.notes: Low sugar due to bitter liqueurs
